author: Luis Cruz
subject: DVD regions
body:
> profits, the licensing and distribution of media is a commercial enterprise.
> It's not fair to expect people's kids to go hungry so you can watch free
> movies.

This is not about watching free movies or eliminating profits; DVD regions
are about the movie studios attempting to control markets, limiting a 
consumer's choice, and potentially gouging markets.

For example, a title is going to be released in the US and Japan.  The studio
decides that the US version will be released in Jan. for $20; the Japanese
version will be released in May for $40.  If DVD region coding was enforced
(i.e., no region-free players, etc.), the Japanese consumer would have no
choice but to pay twice as much for the title.

Now, what if the US version had a commentary track and the Japanese version
did not?  Again, the Japanese consumer would have no choice but to chose
the version that is not only twice as expensive but half as good.

> bootlegging (I know no-one even mentioned bootlegging, but it's relevant)

Bootlegging is not relevant to a discussion about DVD region coding.  DVD
region coding does not even come close to addressing bootlegging.  A bootleg
can be made onto an inferior medium regardless of region coding.  Bootlegging
would be relevant to a discussion of the encryption used on DVDs as well
as Macrovision (and similar content protection schemes).

I do not recall the post previous to yours, so I am basing the above on the
fact that you quoted only a piece about region coding.  If the previous
post went on about encryption/copy protection, then I am in error.

> Lupin^_^) but with stuff that does get distributed here, if you don't buy
> that release, that's a vote against licensing anime in North America.  If
> no-one makes any money on it, they can't do it.

If a similar product exists in a different region/country, why should I not
have the choice to vote with my dollar for the product which I feel is 
superior?  If a US company brings over an anime title and does a poor job
in mastering it to DVD, why should I vote for them with my dollar?  They will
have no incentive to produce better quality DVDs.  

I would rather have the choice to vote with my dollar for the version that
I feel is better.  In essence, I am telling the US company "You want my dollar?
Produce a DVD of the same quality as the version from X."  DVD region coding
was put in place to prevent this.  If I want to import a legitimate copy of a 
DVD from another company, I should be free to do that.

One last example.  Let's say a native Frenchman moves to the US to work.  Sony
decides to release a title in the US without a French language track; Sony
also releases the same title in France with a French language track.  Why
should the Frenchman not be able to choose to import the version from France?

Not region coded related, but here is a solid, recent example of a movie
studio trying to price gouge a market:
http://www.smh.com.au/news/0201/26/national/national25.html
